content:
Diagnosis:	Metastatic prostate cancer - osteoclast-rich undifferentiated carcinoma

Stage:		T4N1M1b with extensive bone metastases (superscan appearance on bone scan)

Biomarkers:	PSA risen from 892 to 1240 ng/mL over 4 weeks
	GATA2 positive on molecular testing

Treatment:	Androgen deprivation therapy since January 2024
	Docetaxel chemotherapy commenced March 2024 - stopped after 2 cycles due to deterioration

Current Status:	Significant clinical deterioration

[redacted name] has unfortunately experienced rapid progression of his prostate cancer despite initial hormone therapy and attempted docetaxel. His performance status has declined from 1 to 3 over six weeks, with increasing bone pain requiring opiate escalation and new onset spinal cord compression symptoms affecting T8-T10 levels. Recent MRI spine confirms epidural disease at these levels with cord compression. His PSA has risen further to 1240 despite castrate testosterone levels.

I have discussed his case at today's MDT. Given his rapid progression through first-line treatment and declining performance status, we have agreed to proceed with urgent radiotherapy to T8-T10 (20Gy in 5 fractions) starting tomorrow. We will then consider cabazitaxel as second-line therapy if his performance status improves following radiotherapy and steroids. He understands the poor prognosis and has been referred to palliative care for additional support. We will review him after completion of radiotherapy in 10 days.

primary_cancer.metastases: extensive bone metastases with superscan appearance, epidural metastases T8-T10

cancer_timeline.value: Docetaxel stopped after 2 cycles due to clinical deterioration
PSA risen to 1240 despite castrate testosterone levels
MRI confirms epidural disease with cord compression at T8-T10

patient_facts.value: Performance status deteriorated from 1 to 3 over six weeks
Increasing bone pain requiring opiate escalation
Spinal cord compression symptoms at T8-T10 levels

status_updates.value: Aggressive metastatic prostate cancer with rapid progression through first-line therapy and development of cord compression. Significant clinical deterioration with poor prognosis
Disease progression on ADT and docetaxel with rising PSA and new cord compression
Docetaxel discontinued due to clinical deterioration
Significant decline in performance status from 1 to 3 over six weeks
Urgent radiotherapy to T8-T10 starting tomorrow, referred to palliative care, review in 10 days
